means: （由失败等引起的）懊恼，懊丧，悔恨

sentence.Network_en: Much to his chagrin, he did not win the race.
sentence.Network_cn: 使他大为懊恼的是他赛跑没获胜.

sentence.Network_en: One of the first things we did when we moved in, to the chagrin of the architect, was to replace the leaded windows.
sentence.Network_cn: 让建筑师大为懊恼的是，我们搬进去最先做的事情之一就是换掉了花饰铅条窗。

sentence.Network_en: His increasingly visible chagrin sets up a vicious circle.
sentence.Network_cn: 他的明显的不满引起了一种恶性循环.

derivation.yuyuan_name: mid 17th cent. (in the sense 'melancholy'): from French chagrin (noun), literally 'rough skin, shagreen', chagriner (verb), of unknown origin

entry.def: Chagrin is a feeling of disappointment, upset, or annoyance, perhaps because of your own failure.

example.ex: One of the first things we did when we moved in, to the chagrin of the architect, was to replace the leaded windows.
example.tran: 让建筑师大为懊恼的是，我们搬进去最先做的事情之一就是换掉了花饰铅条窗。

means.word_mean: 1. cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of;

sentences.sentence: "He humiliated his colleague by criticising him in front of the boss"

auth_sentence.content: The Indian people have watched the mockery of governance with anguish and chagrin.
auth_sentence.res_content: The Indian people have watched the mockery of governance with anguish and chagrin.
auth_sentence.res_content_con: The Indian people have watched the mockery of governance with anguish and chagrin.

auth_sentence.content: Twenty years later, student revolutionaries mounted the barricades gaily chanting Merde au chagrin!

auth_sentence.res_content_con: Twenty years later, student revolutionaries mounted the barricades gaily chanting Merde au chagrin!

auth_sentence.content: They express the sore chagrin of a movement looking for heirs and finding none.
auth_sentence.res_content: They express the sore chagrin of a movement looking for heirs and finding none.
